Introduction

Scleroderma is a family of autoimmune connective tissue disorders characterized by an obliterative vasculopathy leading to fibrosis of the skin and internal organs.  It carries high morbidity and mortality due to involvement of the lungs, kidneys, heart, and gastrointestinal tract.

Pathogenesis

Scleroderma is thought to arise from the interplay of vasculopathy, autoimmunity, and fibrogenesis (

figure 1
).

Vasculopathy

The initial events in scleroderma are thought to begin in the small vessels.  Microvascular injuries may be related to antiendothelial antibodies, upregulated cell adhesion molecules (eg, ICAM-1), and altered balance of vasoconstrictors versus vasodilators (eg, high endothelin, low nitric oxide).  These changes may contribute to patients having increased vasospasticity of digital arteries (eg, Raynaud phenomenon) and pulmonary arteries.  Vessel lumens are narrowed due to neointimal hyperplasia, smooth muscle hypertrophy, and concentric "onion skin" fibrosis.

Autoimmunity

Microvascular injury triggers a complex immune response (eg, T cells, NK cells, many cytokines) that further damages surrounding tissues.  The resultant exposure of intracellular contents promotes the formation of autoantibodies (eg, anticentromere), which are seen in >90% of patients.  Some autoantibodies can bind and activate fibroblasts.

Fibrogenesis

Profibrotic cytokines (eg, platelet derived growth factor, transforming growth factor-êžµ) are markedly upregulated in scleroderma.  Fibroblasts are highly proliferative and constitutively active, secreting large amounts of extracellular matrix (mainly collagen).

Histopathology is uncommonly obtained but can show dermal thickening with sheets of collagen deposition (

image 1
) and obliterated arteries with medial hypertrophy and perivascular fibrosis (
image 2
).

Risk factors

Risk factors for developing scleroderma include:

  • Immunogenetics:  Certain HLA haplotypes are strongly linked with scleroderma (eg, DQ7).  These may code for major histocompatibility complex (MHC) molecules that abnormally express self-antigens and activate T cells.  Non-HLA gene associations include polymorphisms in fibrillin-1 (extracellular matrix regulator), IL-23 (T-cell potentiator), and others.
  • Demographics:  Middle-aged women (eg, 30-50) are at highest risk of scleroderma, with a 4:1 predominance over men.  However, men with scleroderma have a worse prognosis (due to greater interstitial lung fibrosis) than women.  The cause of this sex gap is unknown.
  • Industrial exposures:  Prolonged exposure to silica (eg, mining), vinyl chloride (eg, plastic workers), and organic solvents (eg, toluene) are associated with scleroderma, particularly in men.

Classification

Scleroderma is first classified in 1 of 2 ways:

  • Localized (skin only)
  • Systemic (skin + internal organs)

Systemic sclerosis is further subclassified as

  • Limited cutaneous
  • Diffuse cutaneous

These forms have different patterns of skin involvement, visceral organ involvement, and autoantibody associations (

).

Localized sclerosis

Morphea

Morphea are thickened, hardened plaques of fibrotic skin (

image 3
).  Morphea are typically few (eg, â‰¤3) and distributed asymmetrically on the torso, abdomen, and proximal limbs (eg, upper arms and thighs).  The fibrosis is typically limited to the dermis but can extend into subdermal layers such as fascia and muscle (ie, deep morphea).  The plaques can cause tightness, pain, and restricted range of motion.  Permanent contractures can develop for lesions spanning joints.  Rarely, large chest wall morphea can cause pulmonary restriction (corset effect).

Linear scleroderma 

Linear scleroderma refers to long bands of deep and disfiguring morphea, often following a dermatomal distribution (

image 4
).  Due to the depth of fibrosis, lesions can have a sunken, furrowed, atrophic appearance.  The face, forehead, and scalp are most commonly affected ("en coup de sabre" = sword wound).

Systemic sclerosis

Limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis

Limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis is associated with anticentromere antibodies.  Skin involvement is limited to the face and distal extremities (eg, beyond the elbow).  The classic presentation is CREST syndrome:

  • Calcinosis cutis:  Calcium deposits occur in areas of chronic sclerotic injury, leading to areas of chalky, hardened skin (ie, a form of dystrophic calcification) (
    image 5
    ).
  • Raynaud phenomenon:  Episodic vasoconstriction causes painful ischemia of the fingers (and occasionally the nose or ears).  The digits transition from white (ischemic pallor) to blue (cyanosis) to red (reperfusion) (
    image 6
    ).  Nailbeds show loss of capillary loops.  Ischemia can lead to ulceration (
    image 7
    ) or autoamputation in severe cases.
  • Esophageal dysmotility:  Fibrosis of the esophageal wall causes aperistalsis, leading to dysphagia and gastroesophageal reflux (often severe, causing recurrent aspiration).  Imaging may show a dilated and fluid-filled esophagus (
    image 8
    ).
  • Sclerodactyly:  Fibrosis and tightening of the fingers (
    image 9
    ) results in a taut, shiny appearance.  Fixed flexion contractures are common.
  • Telangiectasias:  Microvascular changes lead to formation of tiny, dilated, spidery blood vessels, particularly on the face (
    image 10
    ).  Subungual (nailbed) telangiectasias are specific to scleroderma (eg, helping to differentiate from photoaging).

In addition to these findings, patients characteristically have facial tightening, lending a stern mask-like demeanor (eg, difficulty smiling), thin lips, and a small oral opening.  Limited cutaneous scleroderma is associated with less skin involvement but more prominent vascular features, such as Raynaud phenomenon, telangiectasias, and pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH).  Its course is typically more indolent than the diffuse form of scleroderma; it has a better prognosis.  However, symptoms can still be debilitating, and the presence of PAH is associated with worse outcomes due to right ventricular failure.

Diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis

Diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis is associated with anti-topoisomerase I (anti-Scl-70) antibodies.  Skin involvement is more extensive, often involving sections of the trunk and proximal extremities.  Visceral organ involvement is more common, including:

  • Interstitial lung disease:  Scleroderma-related interstitial lung disease (ILD) mainly takes the form of nonspecific interstitial pneumonia (NSIP: patchy reticular infiltrates and ground glass along a bronchovascular distribution, with subpleural sparing) (
    image 11
    ) or usual interstitial pneumonia (UIP: bibasilar reticular infiltrates and subpleural honeycombing) (
    image 12
    ).  Patients have dyspnea, hypoxemia, and dry inspiratory crackles.  Pulmonary function shows a restrictive pattern with reduced DLCO.  The clinical course is marked by chronic progression punctuated by acute exacerbations (eg, triggered by viral respiratory infection).
  • Scleroderma renal crisis:  Renal arteriospasm and vascular obliteration causes decreased filtration and intense activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS).  The result is acute kidney injury (AKI) and hypertensive emergency (eg, neurologic changes, pulmonary edema).  Red blood cells are forcefully sheared through fibrin in damaged vessels (eg, microangiopathic hemolytic anemia).  Risk factors include high doses of systemic corticosteroids (eg, increased sodium retention and vasoconstriction) and anti-RNA polymerase III antibodies.
  • Other visceral manifestations include cardiac fibrosis (eg, diastolic dysfunction, conduction blocks, myopericarditis, pericardial effusion), biliary cirrhosis (scarring of bile ducts leading to progressive cholestasis), and gastrointestinal disease (eg, gastroparesis, small bowel overgrowth from gut dysmotility, recurrent bleeding from angiodysplasias [watermelon stomach]).  Diffuse cutaneous scleroderma has a more aggressive course with a worse prognosis than limited cutaneous scleroderma; ILD and cardiac disease are the major causes of death.
  • Systemic sclerosis sine scleroderma:  Approximately 10% of patients have visceral organ fibrosis (systemic sclerosis) without skin involvement (sine scleroderma).  This is clinically relevant during evaluation of ILD, pulmonary arterial hypertension, or unexplained esophageal dysmotility; testing for scleroderma autoantibodies is indicated even in the absence of skin findings.
  • Scleroderma overlap syndromes:  Approximately 10% of patients with scleroderma also display features of another autoimmune disorder.  Examples include scleroderma-systemic lupus erythematosus overlap (eg, +dsDNA antibodies, photosensitivity, and serositis), scleroderma-rheumatoid arthritis overlap (eg, +rheumatoid factor, joint swelling, morning stiffness), and scleroderma-dermatomyositis overlap (eg, +antisynthetase antibodies, heliotrope rash, elevated creatine kinase).

Treatment

General approach

  • Systemic immunosuppression:  Most cases of systemic sclerosis (ie, internal organ involvement) call for immunosuppression.  Commonly used agents include methotrexate, mycophenolate, and cyclophosphamide.  Systemic glucocorticoids are avoided due to their risk of precipitating scleroderma renal crisis; however, they may be used as a last resort (briefly and at lowest doses) in patients with life-threatening inflammation (eg, myocarditis).
  • Local therapy:  Discrete patches of morphea can be treated with topical or intralesional glucocorticoids or phototherapy (UV-A light).
  • Supportive care:  Physical and occupational therapy is recommended to preserve range of motion and manual dexterity.  Nonhealing wounds (eg, digital ulcerations) generally do not respond to debridement (eg, worsens fibrosis) and require constant protection and moisturization.

Management of specific complications

  • Renal crisis:  Scleroderma renal crisis is defined as an abrupt rise in blood pressure, acute kidney injury (typically with normal urine sediment), and/or evidence of microangiopathic hemolytic anemia (eg, schistocytes, thrombocytopenia).  Patients require hospital admission for immediate antihypertensive therapy (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 2
    ).  High-dose ACE inhibitors (eg, intravenous enalaprilat, PO captopril) are the drugs of choice.  (Scleroderma renal crisis is a unique clinical situation where acute renal failure is treated with ACE inhibitors, which are avoided in other types of AKI).  Additional vasodilators (eg, nicardipine, nitroprusside) may be needed.  Most patients continue on lifelong ACE inhibitor therapy.
  • ILD:  Scleroderma ILD is treated with immunosuppression, as described above, although methotrexate is generally avoided.  Antifibrotic therapy (eg, nintedanib) can also slow the rate of lung function decline.  Lung transplantation may be considered, but is often limited by poor functional status, fibrosis of other organs, and a high risk of aspiration pneumonia due to esophageal dysmotility.
  • PAH:  Scleroderma PAH is treated with pulmonary vasodilator therapy, typically a combination of a phosphodiesterase-5 inhibitor (eg, tadalafil) and endothelin receptor antagonist (eg, bosentan).  Prostaglandins (eg, epoprostenol) are added for severe PAH or refractory Raynaud phenomenon.  Cautious volume status management (eg, diuretics) is required for right ventricular failure.
  • Gastrointestinal disease:  Esophageal dysmotility and gastroparesis usually require drastic dietary changes and lifelong antacid therapy (eg, proton pump inhibitors).  Prokinetic agents (eg, metoclopramide) can help.  Surgical intervention (eg, fundoplication) is generally contraindicated due to the high risk of worsened gastroesophageal fibrosis and recurrence.  Small intestinal bacterial overgrowth requires treatment with antibiotic therapy (eg, rifaximin).  Gastric bleeding (from angiodysplasias) is treated with endoscopic laser coagulation.

Allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT) is the only known curative treatment for refractory systemic sclerosis.  The mechanism of remission (eg, reversal of fibrosis) is not understood.  However, HSCT is rarely possible due to poor functional status and extent of underlying chronic organ dysfunction.

Summary

Scleroderma is an autoimmune connective tissue disorder characterized by vasculopathy, fibrosis, and autoimmunity, leading to significant morbidity and mortality due to involvement of the skin and internal organs.  Pathogenesis is poorly understood but involves microvascular injury, immune dysregulation, and excessive fibrosis.  Scleroderma is classified as localized (morphea) or systemic sclerosis, with systemic sclerosis further divided into limited or diffuse cutaneous forms.

  • Limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis is associated with anticentromere antibodies and CREST syndrome (eg, Raynaud phenomenon, telangiectasias) and pulmonary arterial hypertension.
  • Diffuse cutaneous scleroderma is associated with anti-topoisomerase I (Scl-70) antibodies and aggressive visceral organ involvement (eg, interstitial lung disease, renal crisis, cardiac fibrosis).

Treatment typically involves immunosuppressive therapies (eg, methotrexate, cyclophosphamide) and organ-directed therapies (eg, antifibrotics for interstitial lung disease, pulmonary vasodilators for pulmonary arterial hypertension).  Prognosis is worse for diffuse systemic sclerosis, with most deaths due to progressive interstitial lung disease.
